metadata.subject: FW: RE : RE: Revised letter. Arbitrary detention of Mr. Wade

organizations: U.S. House Committee on Oversight and Accountability
United Nations Working Group of Arbitrary Detention
House Committee on the District of Columbia
Post Office and Civil Service Committee

relationships.description: Colleagues at Nelson Mullins law firm working on Senegal political case
Working together on advocacy campaign for Karim Wade's release
Political rivals in Senegal, with Sall having Wade imprisoned

analysis.purpose: Coordinate advocacy efforts to secure release of Karim Wade from detention in Senegal and influence US policy
analysis.significance: Shows US-based lobbying efforts to influence African politics and US foreign policy regarding Senegal's democratic practices

notable_quotes: The United Nations Working Group of Arbitrary Detention determined that Mr. Wade was arbitrarily arrested and that his detention was in violation of international law.
President Macky Sall reneged on his commitment to shorten term limits. Instead of holding elections next year, after five years per his commitment, he announced that he would serve until 2019.
The destabilization of democracy in Senegal could have significant consequences in the entire region. The United States must get in front of this negative trend before spreads across Africa.
red_flags: Political advocacy for detained foreign political figure
Coordinated media campaign to influence US foreign policy

blackmail_indicators.description: No indicators of blackmail or coercion found. Communication appears to be legitimate political advocacy work.

illegal_activity.description: No illegal activity discussed or evidenced. Document concerns legitimate political advocacy and legal work.

details: Article published in The Hill newspaper
Mention of Amnesty International human rights report
Discussion of media strategy and timing of publications

public_knowledge.context: The detention of Karim Wade and democratic backsliding in Senegal were publicly reported issues in 2015-2016. The Hill article mentioned would have been publicly available.

analysis.summary: Email chain discussing successful placement of an article in The Hill about Senegal's democratic backsliding and the arbitrary detention of Karim Wade. The communication coordinates advocacy efforts involving US lawmakers and State Department officials to pressure Senegal's government to release Wade and uphold democratic principles.
